I would like to thank our entire community for your adaptability through this challenging time.

Stay safe and healthy.

Thank you,
Dr. Paul J. Padalino
Superintendent of Schools

Classroom Highlight
Farmers and staff from Hudson Valley Farm Hub and the Kingston YMCA Farm Project visited George Washington Elementary to give lessons on corn crops, describing the many varieties of corn species that can be grown locally and how corn produces masa (cornmeal) to use for cooking. The lesson was offered in both English and Spanish so students could hear each translation of the entire presentation. Students learned how corn is planted, harvested, dried, and ground before a hands-on demonstration using masa to make tortillas. From rolling the dough to pressing and cooking the tortillas, students finished the workshop with an edible treat to taste!

Kingston City School District’s Health & Wellness Committee supports cooking in the classroom as it is a valuable life skill that also promotes healthy eating. Children who assist with meal preparation are typically more adventurous eaters and learn that healthy foods can taste great. Cooking can also be a great time to practice math and reading skills in a practical setting.

George Washington Elementary KCSD

Another Feel Good Friday story!

George Washington Montessori honored World Kindness Day (Nov. 13) on November 15th with a morning assembly to start Friday and the weekend on a positive note. Students on stage sang a song about kindness before a student-made video was viewed, showing a compilation of clips about what kindness is to them.

Students in the video represented all grade levels at the school and inspired others to be kind, by giving a hug, standing up for your friends, helping someone up, respecting others, being nice, loving people, and playing with someone who doesn’t have anyone to play with.

Principal LoBianco closed the assembly with a poem reading that resonates with all:

Spread a little kindness
Everywhere you go
Let that little kindness
From your heart, gently flow

Reach out with kindness
To all those in need
Smile at others with kindness
Spread the kindness seed

Be kind today, and every day
(Poem is from JollyGreets.com)

Have a great weekend and celebrate kindness with us!

He has served as Principal for the Summer Nine Program for five years and has played a critical role in the management of the building throughout the Second Century Project.

“Mr. DeCicco has 16 years of experience at Kingston High School and has been an integral part of the great strides we’ve taken there. He has intimate knowledge of the procedures, policies and programs already in place at KHS and I look forward to watching him grow in this new role,” said Superintendent Dr. Paul J. Padalino.

Please join the KCSD in congratulating Vince as he takes on his new role as Principal and leader of the Kingston Tigers.

2019 Speakers and Topics:
Tyana Gaton – Why Speaking to Your Children About Disabilities is Important
Kira Milgrim – The Roots of Gender Discrepancy
Maggie Noe – Money in Politics
Aleca Pardo – Sexual Assault
Xavier Sharp – Biracial Ignorance
Mealea Van Denburg – Importance of Music Programs in School

Kingston High School honored the men and women who have died while serving in the U.S. military at the Annual Memorial Day Ceremony.

Members of the STAR Club Honor Guard presented and raised the American Flag on the front lawn of the high school, accompanied by the Star Spangled Banner, played by the KHS Band.

Kingston Mayor, Steve Noble, welcomed staff and students and thanked everyone for wanting to take part in this important ceremony.

A chilling rendition of Taps was played from the balcony to honor our fallen soldiers.

The poem "In Flanders Field", by John McCrae was read by Devin Canonico, and Jadah Gallo read her student reflection "What Memorial Day Means to Me."

In his closing remarks, Principal Reinhardt reminded students to "take some time on Monday to remember why we have the day off."

*KHS STAR Club Honor Guard: Devin Canonico, Jadah Gallo, Muhammad Hussan Shabbir, Russell Diers, Mason Alexander Longendyke

Educators are always finding innovative ways to keep lessons exciting. Skype calls with fascinating people on the other end of the screen is one way KCSD teachers and instructional coaches have brought lessons to life.

Students asked the entrepreneur a number of questions about his business and location technology while he was in his New York City office. Later that afternoon, Mr. Crowley tweeted about his encounter with these amazing fourth-graders. They are on his map!

Thank you, Mr. Crowley and Mr. Circe for a great experience!

There are a couple more days to see the Pop-Up Gallery Group (PUGG) Alumni Exhibition displayed on the first floor of Kingston's City Hall, which features work created by KHS Alumni. Monday, March 25, is the final day of the show.

The PUGG program is an arts management program developed to support current and alumni artists of Kingston High School. The program was developed by Lara Giordano and JoAnna Ruisi of The Department of Regional Art Workers (The DRAW), and was originally funded through a grant from the Department of Economic & Community Development of the City of Kingston. The PUGG program connects Kingston High School Alumni with local exhibition & workshop opportunities, along with providing current Kingston High School students with valuable experience in arts management.

In photo: “Island” by Frank D. Pesko, KHS Class of 2008

More info: www.kingston-ny.gov/exhibitions

George Washington Elementary School had a surprise visitor earlier this week! Representative Antonio Delgado came to Sherilyn Hixson's Kindergarten classroom to read the children a book called "On the Farm, at the Market" by G. Brian Karas.
His visit was a part of the New York State’s Agricultural Literacy Week and was arranged by the Cornell Cooperative Extension’s “Eat Smart New York Hudson Valley.”
Students learned about fruits and vegetables grown on a farm and brought to market. Then they got to play a game where they had to sell produce at a farmer’s market.
The students at George Washington were excited to meet the Congressman, and said he is a very good storyteller.

After wrapping up their regular winter season (W-5, L-6), the Boys Varsity Swim Team is heading to the Section 9 Championships at Valley Central High School on Thursday, February 14, 2019, through Saturday, February 16. Swimming prelims will commence on Thursday with finals concluding on Saturday. Diving prelims and finals will be held on Friday afternoon.

The team will compete in nine races and one diving event: 50 Freestyle Diving, 200 Medley Relay, 200 Freestyle, 200 Individual Medley, 100 Butterfly, 500 Freestyle, 200 Freestyle Relay, 100 Backstroke, 100 Breaststroke, and the 400 Freestyle Relay.

"These young men worked hard all season and have never given up. We are a young, small team, but we have a lot of heart," said Coach Chris Sammons. "Traditions that have been consistent in all of the teams that I have coached has been the trust in the program, determination that each athlete has and the support that they show their teammates. This team is no different, I am very proud of this them. Go Tigers!"

We second that... GO TIGERS!!!

Did you know that there is a proposition on the upcoming Kingston City School District ballot about Dietz Stadium?

"Proposition 4 - Conveyance of Dietz Stadium to the City of Kingston"

What does this proposition mean?

Voting YES on this proposition would allow the Board of Education to hold a vote on whether or not to transfer full ownership of Dietz Stadium, which hosts athletic events for the students and community, to the City. Currently, the City of Kingston and the Kingston City School District each have 50% ownership of the Stadium. Voting YES would NOT automatically transfer ownership to the City. Rather, it would give the Board of Education the opportunity to discuss the issue and hold a vote on whether or not to transfer ownership.
